key_facts: Japanese researchers found microplastics in cloud water.
Microplastics were found in samples from Mount Fuji.
Microplastics were found in samples from Mount Oyama.
Microplastic concentrations ranged from 6.7 to 13.9 particles per litre.
The study was published in *Environmental Chemistry Letters*.
Nine types of plastic polymers and rubber were identified.
Particle sizes ranged from 7.1 to 94.6 micrometres.
Microplastics in the upper atmosphere may degrade under UV radiation.
Degraded microplastics may release greenhouse gases.
Microplastics may contribute to climate change.
Airborne microplastics may be part of a 'plastic rainfall' cycle.
Plastic rainfall may contaminate food supplies.
Plastic rainfall may contaminate water supplies.
Waseda University highlighted microplastics in human organs.
The findings highlight the global impact of plastic pollution.
